looking for a cheap webcam

27 Jul 2007 Thinking about the mini-house for mice I want to build, I obviously want to have webcams inside to see what goes on.
All kinds of other projects are screaming for webcams too, so the quest for a cheap USB webcam has begun.

The cheapest one I can find right now is one from Conceptronic codenamed CLLCLIQCAM

It costs 12 euro at MPL

wooden frames constructed

27 Jul 2007 I finished building 2 wooden frames to hold the plastic. Pictures can be found here:
[G2:11574]

A couple of things to note:

First, don't believe anything coming from a hardwarestore. Well, maybe not anything, but still it's a good idea to doublecheck it.
As you can see on this picture [G2:11592], the width of my planks is not 36 but 35mm.

Also, it doesn't look like any of the planks I bought was straight. I didn't notice it at the store because all 10 were tied well together. So keep that in mind...

This is what my frames look like in the vacuform rack
[G2:11613]

wooden frame

25 Jul 2007 Another trip to the hardware store !

This time, I went looking for things to construct the plastic-holding frames with. Many vacuform-builders use square metal tubing. A meter of metal tube of 15 by 15mm costs 4 euro. Since I need 8 of those (2 frames), that would be 32 euro. It's probably worth the money, but I'm not sure I can build the frame without destroying something. To construct a metal frame, I'd need to weld pieces together, or at least braze them together in case of aluminum.

To play it safe, I will construct a wooden frame first. I bought 10 pieces of 210cm each: 18mm by 36mm. I bought 10 of them because that only cost me 13.30 euro if I bought them together.

I also got 8 L-shaped profiles (60mmx60mmx18mm) for 4 euro in total. The profiles come with screws.

Later today I hope to begin the construction of the frames.

I've also noticed that they sell nice hinges at the hardwarestore, which I will probably buy to create the lever-system. More on that later...

Velleman K8048 - VM111 PIC programmer

25 Jul 2007 A couple days ago, I bought a PIC programmer from Velleman. It requires a 12V or 15V power supply which was not in the package when I bought it. Luckily, we have a big box of 12V power adaptors at work (each FOT comes with one and we don't use them, so we have A LOT of them. Maybe I should take a picture...)

Now I have a 12V adaptor and it works nicely with the K8048. The software that came with it is Windows only, so I had to reboot (after making an image of the CD under linux... you never know)

[rant]
Whenever I boot Windows, every tiny program I run starts bugging me about needing to be upgraded. What a fine concept! Programs that can detect if they are out of date all by themselves. That's really great! Now if only they could just go ahead and update themselves without redirecting me to a website where I would have to manually download a new .exe or zip-file and run it, now THAT would be even better.

Best of all though would be that MS Windows came with a decent package manager bt default like most (if not all) Linux distributions do since the last half decade.
[/rant]

Anyway, the program to program the PIC works fine. There is also an assembler on the CD to compile a second demo program. It runs fine as well, as long as you don't put the assembler code anywhere you like. You see, it can't work with pathnames longer than 62 characters in length. What a load of crap...

Luckily, there are plenty of better compilers under Linux. The program remains the programmer though... There is an opensource tool for that, but it's not in apt :(

Perhaps I can run the thing from virtualbox or vmware, and trap whatever goes over the serial line...
